177: I have given my name and my day-clothes up to the nurses

182: The nurses pass and pass, they are no trouble,

195: They have swabbed me clear of my loving associations.

207: The tulips are too red in the first place, they hurt me.
208: Even through the gift paper I could hear them breathe
209: Lightly, through their white swaddlings, like an awful baby.
210: Their redness talks to my wound, it corresponds.
211: They are subtle: they seem to float, though they weigh me down,
212: Upsetting me with their sudden tongues and their color,
213: A dozen red lead sinkers round my neck.
214: Nobody watched me before, now I am watched.
215: The tulips turn to me, and the window behind me
216: Where once a day the light slowly widens and slowly thins,
217: And I see myself, flat, ridiculous, a cut-paper shadow
218: Between the eye of the sun and the eyes of the tulips,
219: And I have no face, I have wanted to efface myself.
220: The vivid tulips eat my oxygen.
221: Before they came the air was calm enough,

223: Then the tulips filled it up like a loud noise.

729: THE MOON AND THE YEW TREE
730: This is the light of the mind, cold and planetary.
731: The trees of the mind are black. The light is blue.
732: The grasses unload their griefs on my feet as if I were God,
733: Prickling my ankles and murmuring of their humility.
734: Fumy, spiritous mists inhabit this place
735: Separated from my house by a row of headstones.
736: I simply cannot see where there is to get to.
737: The moon is no door. It is a face in its own right,
738: White as a knuckle and terribly upset.
739: It drags the sea after it like a dark crime; it is quiet
740: With the O-gape of complete despair. I live here.
741: Twice on Sunday, the bells startle the sky—
742: Eight great tongues affirming the Resurrection.
743: At the end, they soberly bong out their names.
744: The yew tree points up. It has a Gothic shape.
745: The eyes lift after it and find the moon.
746: The moon is my mother. She is not sweet like Mary.
747: Her blue garments unloose small bats and owls.
748: How I would like to believe in tenderness—
749: The face of the effigy, gentled by candles,
750: Bending, on me in particular, its mild eyes.
751: I have fallen a long way. Clouds are flowering
752: Blue and mystical over the face of the stars.
753: Inside the church, the saints will be all blue,
754: Floating on their delicate feet over the cold pews,
755: Their hands and faces stiff with holiness.
756: The moon sees nothing of this. She is bald and wild.
757: And the message of the yew tree is blackness—blackness and silence.
